elements.content: Interpenetration or catenation is well explored in the network structure of metal organic frameworks, but these kinds of networks were considered as not usable for normal applications of conventional open metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). Recently, flexibility in such networks was found to be an important factor to introduce functionality in the structures of MOFs, and also, the understanding of the factors that control interpenetration also become important. To date, there is no obvious root that has been found to have an interpenetrated network with successive flexibility. In search of such types of networks and to explore the avenue of understanding of growing interpenetration in a framework, six new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) of Cu­(II), Cd­(II), and Zn­(II) have been synthesized from three flexible dicarboxylates and two rigid dicarboxylates along with 2-methyl-1-(4-(2-methyl-1H-imidazole-1-yl)­butyl)-1H-imidazole, as a coligand. All of these synthesized complexes have been characterized by single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction and were further characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy (IR), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). N2, CO2, H2, and CH4 sorption studies were also done for all the MOFs, and the characteristic surface adsorptions were found in all cases. Here, from the studies of all these complexes, a common observation is found: flexible dicarboxylates give a noninterpenetrated framework whereas rigid linkers give an interpenetrated framework.

All of these synthesized complexes have been characterized by single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction and were further characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy (IR), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). N2, CO2, H2, and CH4 sorption studies were also done for all the MOFs, and the characteristic surface adsorptions were found in all cases. elements.content: Six coordination polymers have been synthesized from a flexible bis-imidazolyl linker and different rigid and flexible dicarboxylates, where the rigidity of the dicarboxylates is the controlling factor for generating interpenetration in the overall framework.
elements.clean_text: Six coordination polymers have been synthesized from a flexible bis-imidazolyl linker and different rigid and flexible dicarboxylates, where the rigidity of the dicarboxylates is the controlling factor for generating interpenetration in the overall framework.

elements.content: Interpenetration of network structure has been considered as an important parameter to monitor in the design and synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal organic frameworks (MOFs). Among the innumerable reported MOFs, various types of interpenetration networks as well as polycatenation have been reported vividly and discussed when required. At the beginning, such frameworks were believed to be nonporous and hence considered unsuitable for exhibiting some of the functionalities desired in MOFs. Thus, discussions were restrained in the theoretical interests and basic understanding, whereas the designing principles of such interpenetration and/or polycatenation frameworks are limited to a few MOFs only. The restraints are mainly due to the inaccessible voids in the framework. But, some recent works have shown that, due to structural transformability, some interpenetrated structures are also found capable of exhibiting accessible voids in their transformed structures. Thus, these transformable interpenetrated MOFs can display functionalities similar to their noninterpenetrated analogue structures. This observation has geared up the searching for new types of materials called flexible MOFs which show physical/chemical transformation in the presence of external stimuli due to the reorganization of their structures. As a result the exploration of the tuning of interpenetration in the structure of MOFs is a current demand which has not yet been illuminated in detail.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Interpenetration of network structure has been considered as an important parameter to monitor in the design and synthesis of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal organic frameworks (MOFs). Among the innumerable reported MOFs, various types of interpenetration networks as well as polycatenation have been reported vividly and discussed when required. At the beginning, such frameworks were believed to be nonporous and hence considered unsuitable for exhibiting some of the functionalities desired in MOFs. Thus, discussions were restrained in the theoretical interests and basic understanding, whereas the designing principles of such interpenetration and/or polycatenation frameworks are limited to a few MOFs only. The restraints are mainly due to the inaccessible voids in the framework. But, some recent works have shown that, due to structural transformability, some interpenetrated structures are also found capable of exhibiting accessible voids in their transformed structures. Thus, these transformable interpenetrated MOFs can display functionalities similar to their noninterpenetrated analogue structures. This observation has geared up the searching for new types of materials called flexible MOFs which show physical/chemical transformation in the presence of external stimuli due to the reorganization of their structures. As a result the exploration of the tuning of interpenetration in the structure of MOFs is a current demand which has not yet been illuminated in detail.

elements.content: Among various aspects of forming interpenetration in the structure of MOFs, the nature of the ligand, particularly the length and flexibility of the ligand, has to be considered as one of the important parameters. The flexibility of the ligand sometimes play an important role in the generation of interpenetration in the structure. It is prevalent for mixed ligand MOFs that the combination of polycarboxylates and N-donor ligands is the most efficient way to produce the desired assembly. Among the polycarboxylates both aromatic and aliphatic multidentate polycarboxylates have been chosen frequently as the building blocks in the construction of CPs due to their diverse coordination modes. Whereas in the context of N, N donor linkers like bispyridyl, bisimidazole, bistriazole, etc. have been utilized most extensively to link up metal ions in MOF. Both of these linkers connected by one or more −(CH2)– groups can bring structural diversity in the coordination polymer as these flexible −(CH2)– backbones can take up fickle conformations and geometries via rotating, bending, or twisting; producing diverse structures. These flexible backbones often help to stabilize the network through interpenetration or more complicated polycatenation to avoid the void within the structure. It has been also found that different weak forces have an important role sometime for the generation of the overall interpenetrated structure. To understand the effect of ligand flexibility/rigidity on the creation of interpenetration on the structure, here we have synthesized six new mixed ligand MOFs where a long and quite flexible 2-methyl-1-(4-(2-methyl-1H-imidazole-1-yl)­butyl)-1H-imidazole (2-mbib) has been utilized as a common coligand. In addition to that different dicarboxylates, rigid and flexible has also been utilized in the synthesis with the combination of various metal ions. Here the rigidity in the dicarboxylate has been incorporated by the introduction of double bond or aromatic system in between two carboxylate groups. The synthesized six new MOFs namely, {[Cu­(2-mbib)­(glut)]·(4H2O)} n (1), {[Cd2(2-mbib)2(3-mglut)2]·(solvent) x } n (2), {[Cd­(2-mbib)­(2-mglut)]·(4H2O)} n (3), {[Zn­(2-mbib)­(tp)]·(2H2O)} n (4), {[Cu­(2-mbib)0.5(fum)0.5]·(H2O)} n (5), and {[Cd­(2-mbib)0.5(fum)0.5]·(MeOH)} n (6) contain five different acid salts, disodium glutarate (Na2 glut), 3-methyl glutarate (Na23-mglut), 2-methyl glutarate (Na22-mglut), disodium terepthalate (Na2 tp), and fumarate (Na2 fum) and three different transition metal ions. In this study, flexible glutarate and its derivative, rigid fumarate, and terepthalate are used as anionic ligands. All of these carboxylates have the same binding group and common coligand, but the rigid dicarboxylates produce interpenetrated structures; whereas the nonrigid or flexible dicarboxylate forms noninterpenetrated structures. The detailed synthetic scheme of complexes 1–6 is represented in .

elements.content: Structural analyses for all the complexes have been performed on the basis of single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD). Additional characterization is done by powder XRD and other physicochemical methods. Complexes 1–3 show 2D networks, whereas complexes 4–6 exhibit interpenetrated 3D frameworks. Among 4–6, complex 4 shows 3-fold interpenetrated network and the rest are 4-fold interpenetrated networks. Gas sorption analysis has been performed for all the activated complexes.

Among 4-6, complex 4 shows 3-fold interpenetrated network and the rest are 4-fold interpenetrated networks. Gas sorption analysis has been performed for all the activated complexes.

elements.content: Using the mixed ligand solution in a 1:1 ratio with the metal following the slow diffusion technique, all six compounds have been synthesized. In junction of the two solutions 1:1 H2O:MeOH solution has been added which will act as a buffer to allow the slow diffusion of the two solutions. Detailed process of synthesis has been described in the experimental section given in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

Synthesis

Using the mixed ligand solution in a 1:1 ratio with the metal following the slow diffusion technique, all six compounds have been synthesized. In junction of the two solutions 1:1 H2O:MeOH solution has been added which will act as a buffer to allow the slow diffusion of the two solutions. Detailed process of synthesis has been described in the experimental section given in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Structural variation arises by the different coordination modes and rigidities (or flexibilities) of the acid dianions and by changing the metal center in complexes 1–6. The coordination mode of the dicarboxylates of six coordination polymers is shown in . The detailed structural description of all the complexes is described below.
elements.clean_text:
Different Binding Modes of the Dicarboxylate

Structural variation arises by the different coordination modes and rigidities (or flexibilities) of the acid dianions and by changing the metal center in complexes 1-6. The coordination mode of the dicarboxylates of six coordination polymers is shown in . The detailed structural description of all the complexes is described below.

Single crystal X-ray analysis indicates that the complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. Here with the help of coordination of Cu­(II) metal ion with the ligand N,N′-donor 2-mbib linker and glut2– dicarboxylate, complex 1 constructs a wavy 2D sheet structure. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Cu­(II) ion, one 2-mbib linker, and one glut2– along with four coordinated water molecules. The metal Cu­(II) center adopt a distorted octahedral geometry where four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3 a , and O4 a ) from two different dicarboxylates and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3) from two different 2-mbib are linked to Cu­(II) center. This metal ligand ligation makes CuO4N2 coordination environment around the metal center (a). The Cu–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.992(3) to 2.546(4) Å and the Cu–N bond lengths are 1.990(3) and 1.992(3) Å (Table S1). Glutarate dicarboxylates bridges with two Cu­(II) centers through bis-bidentate chelating fashion to build metal carboxylate zigzag 1D chain which is extended along a-axis (b). These one-dimensional metal dicarboxylate chains are finally attached by 2-mbib, N,N′-donor ligands to construct 2D wavelike sheet structure along crystallographic ac plane (c). The TOPOS analysis of complex 1 reveals that the structure can be represented as a 4-c uninodal net with Schläfli symbol for the net is {44·62} (d). The lattice water molecules between any two 2D layers (Figure S8) are involved in H-bonding with the oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups to build supramolecular 3D structure. There is also C–H···π interaction with in the 2D framework which gives stability of the framework (Figure S9 and Table S2).

elements.content: The single crystal X-ray analysis of complex 2 reveals that it crystallizes in same triclinic P1̅ space group as complex 1. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains two crystallographic independent Cd­(II) ion (Cd1 and Cd2), two 2-mbib, and two 3-mglut2– linkers and solvent molecules. The details structural analysis of complex 2 shows that it has two-dimensional structure built by Cd­(II) ion and two bridging ligand, 2-mbib and 3-mglut2–. Here, both the hexa-coordinated Cd­(II) ions (Cd1 and Cd2) possesses a CdO4N2 coordination environment (a). For each type of Cd­(II) center, four oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms are attached to the metal center to form distorted octahedral geometry around the metal center. For the Cd1 center, the oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O5, and O6) from two different 3-mglut2– are involved whereas four oxygen atoms (O3 a , O4 a , O7, and O8) from two 3-mglut2– ligands are linked to Cd2 centers. In the case of nitrogen ligation, two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N5) from two different 2-mbib ligands are attached to Cd1, and the nitrogen atoms (N4 b and N8 c ) from different 2-mbib ligands are ligated to the Cd2 metal center. The Cd–O lengths vary from 2.327(5) to 2.450(5) Å for the Cd1 center and from 2.287(6) to 2.456(7) Å for Cd2. Cd–N bond lengths are 2.235(5) and 2.267(5) for Cd1 whereas, for Cd2, these bond lengths are 2.217(7) and 2.266(6) Å (Table S3). Each 3-mglut2– binds through bis-bidentate chelating fashion with two different types of Cd­(II) centers (Cd1 and Cd2) to build metal carboxylate zigzag 1D chain which lie in between crystallographic a and b-axis (b). These 1D chains are linked by N,N′-donor 2-mbib linker as complex 1 to construct same type of 2D wavy sheet structure along crystallographic bc-plane (c). Network analysis using TOPOS reveals that the overall structure consists of 4-connected uninodal nets with the point symbol (Schläfli symbol) {44·62} (d). There are both C–H···π and π···π interactions with in the 2D framework which gives the stability of the framework (Figure S10 and Table S4)

The asymmetric unit of 2 contains two crystallographic independent Cd(II) ion (Cd1 and Cd2), two 2-mbib, and two 3-mglut2- linkers and solvent molecules. The details structural analysis of complex 2 shows that it has two-dimensional structure built by Cd(II) ion and two bridging ligand, 2-mbib and 3-mglut2-. Here, both the hexa-coordinated Cd(II) ions (Cd1 and Cd2) possesses a CdO4N2 coordination environment (a). For each type of Cd(II) center, four oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms are attached to the metal center to form distorted octahedral geometry around the metal center. For the Cd1 center, the oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O5, and O6) from two different 3-mglut2- are involved whereas four oxygen atoms (O3 a , O4 a , O7, and O8) from two 3-mglut2- ligands are linked to Cd2 centers. In the case of nitrogen ligation, two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N5) from two different 2-mbib ligands are attached to Cd1, and the nitrogen atoms (N4 b  and N8 c ) from different 2-mbib ligands are ligated to the Cd2 metal center. The Cd-O lengths vary from 2.327(5) to 2.450(5) Å for the Cd1 center and from 2.287(6) to 2.456(7) Å for Cd2. Cd-N bond lengths are 2.235(5) and 2.267(5) for Cd1 whereas, for Cd2, these bond lengths are 2.217(7) and 2.266(6) Å (Table S3). Each 3-mglut2- binds through bis-bidentate chelating fashion with two different types of Cd(II) centers (Cd1 and Cd2) to build metal carboxylate zigzag 1D chain which lie in between crystallographic a and b-axis (b). These 1D chains are linked by N,N'-donor 2-mbib linker as complex 1 to construct same type of 2D wavy sheet structure along crystallographic bc-plane (c). Network analysis using TOPOS reveals that the overall structure consists of 4-connected uninodal nets with the point symbol (Schläfli symbol) {44⋅62} (d). There are both C-H⋅⋅⋅π and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions with in the 2D framework which gives the stability of the framework (Figure S10 and Table S4)

elements.content: Analysis by single crystal X-ray diffraction for complex 3 indicates that it crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group where the Z value is 4. Like complexes 1 and 2, here also a similar type of wavy 2D sheet structure has been constructed for complex 3 by the assembly of the Cd­(II) ion, 2-mglut2–, and 2-mbib ligand. One Cd­(II) ion with one 2-mbib, a 2-mglut2–, and four lattice water molecules together build the asymmetric unit of the complex. Being hexa-coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3, and O4) which comes from two carboxylate groups of two different 2-mglut2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms (N2 and N3) of two different 2-mbib ligands, the metal center creates a CdO4N2 coordination environment and forms a distorted octahedral geometry around the central metal. (a). The Cd–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.235(3)–2.599(4) Å where Cd–N bond lengths are 2.213(3) and 2.306(3) Å (Table S5). The 2-mglut2– linker binds with two Cd­(II) centers through bidentate-chelating fashion which results in the formation of a 1D metal carboxylate chain (b). These 1D chains are finally linked by the 2-mbib ligand following a crisscross fashion to construct a final two-dimensional wavelike sheet structure along the crystallographic ac-plane (c). The TOPOS analysis represents a 4-c uninodal net with a Schläfli symbol of {44·62}­for 3 (d). In the structure of 3 lattice water molecules are also present between the two consecutive 2D sheets (Figure S11) like 1 which helps to form H-bonding by the interaction of solvent molecules with carboxylato-oxygen atom present in the framework.

{[Cd(2-mbib)(2-mglut)]⋅(4H2O)} n  (3)

Analysis by single crystal X-ray diffraction for complex 3 indicates that it crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group where the Z value is 4. Like complexes 1 and 2, here also a similar type of wavy 2D sheet structure has been constructed for complex 3 by the assembly of the Cd(II) ion, 2-mglut2-, and 2-mbib ligand. One Cd(II) ion with one 2-mbib, a 2-mglut2-, and four lattice water molecules together build the asymmetric unit of the complex. Being hexa-coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3, and O4) which comes from two carboxylate groups of two different 2-mglut2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms (N2 and N3) of two different 2-mbib ligands, the metal center creates a CdO4N2 coordination environment and forms a distorted octahedral geometry around the central metal. (a). The Cd-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.235(3)-2.599(4) Å where Cd-N bond lengths are 2.213(3) and 2.306(3) Å (Table S5). The 2-mglut2- linker binds with two Cd(II) centers through bidentate-chelating fashion which results in the formation of a 1D metal carboxylate chain (b). These 1D chains are finally linked by the 2-mbib ligand following a crisscross fashion to construct a final two-dimensional wavelike sheet structure along the crystallographic ac-plane (c). The TOPOS analysis represents a 4-c uninodal net with a Schläfli symbol of {44⋅62}for 3 (d). In the structure of 3 lattice water molecules are also present between the two consecutive 2D sheets (Figure S11) like 1 which helps to form H-bonding by the interaction of solvent molecules with carboxylato-oxygen atom present in the framework.

elements.content: Complex 4 crystallizes in the space group monoclinic C2/c where Z value is 4. The single crystal X-ray analysis of 4 reveals that there is a formation of 3D structure by Zn­(II) ion, tp2– and 2-mbib ligand. The asymmetric unit of 4 is formed by one Zn­(II) ion, one tp2–, one 2-mbib ligand along with two lattice water molecules. The tetracoordinated Zn­(II) ion shows distorted tetrahedral geometry ZnO2N2 coordination environment (a) where Zn (II) ion is attached with two oxygen atoms (O1 and O3) of two dicarboxylate groups of two different tp2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N4 a ) of two different 2-mbib ligands. Here two Zn–O bonds have bond lengths of 1.9527(19) and 1.964(2) Å whereas two Zn–N bond lengths are 1.991(2) and 2.024(3) Å (Table S6). It is interesting to note that, in this structure, each end of tp2– binds with two different Zn­(II) ions through a monodentate fashion and constructs a metal carboxylate 1D chain extended along the crystallographic b-axis (b). These 1D chains are further linked by the 2-mbib ligand forming a 3D structure (c, S13). Each Zn­(II) metal center acts as a 3-connecting node, and the overall structure has Schläfli symbol {103} as analyzed by TOPOS (c). In this structure, the Zn–Zn distance along tp2– is 11.000 and 11.057 Å, and along 2-mbib, it is 9.857 Å (Figure S12). To minimize such a large cavity three of the equivalent frameworks are interpenetrated with each other and produce a 3-fold interpenetrated, 3D framework (d). Thus, the cavity is significantly reduced and the final solvent accessible void is 7.592% (4294.8 Å3) per unit cell volume calculated using PLATON after removal of guest water molecules. Due to the interpenetration there is a generation unidirectional void along the b-axis which is filled up with guest water molecules (Figure S13).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that both the complexes 5 and 6 have 3D structure formed by M­(II) ion (Cu­(II) for 5 and Cd­(II) for 6) with two bridging linkers fum2– and 2-mbib. Both the complexes crystallize in the monoclinic space group P2/n with different Z values, 2 for complex 5 and 4 for complex 6. Both the complexes show the formation of a three-dimensional (3D) network of M­(II) (M = Cu for 5 and Cd for 6) ions connected by the fumarate dianion (fum2–) in a bis bidentate chelating fashion and 2-mbib linker. The asymmetric unit of both 5 and 6 are consisting with one M­(II) ion, half of 2-mbib, half of fum2– and differ only in lattice solvent molecules, containing one lattice water molecule in 5 and one methanol molecule in 6. The hexacoordinated M­(II) ion in both cases shows distorted octahedral geometry with a MO4N2 coordination environment (a for 5 and S15a for 6). Each metal ion is attached with the four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O1 a, and O2 a ) of two different fum2– dicarboxylates whereas two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N1 a ) are coming from two separated 2-mbib ligands. In complexes 5 and 6, the M–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.958(2)–2.719(3) Å (Cu–O for 5), and the Cu–O2 bond length is 2.719(3) which is an elongated bond length and happens due to Jahn–Teller distortion. So the bond becomes labile and of 2.352(4)–2.398(5) Å (Cd–O for 6) whereas both the M–N bond lengths are 1.982(2) Å for 5 and 2.254(3) Å for 6 (Table S7 for 5 and S8 for 6). Here each fum2– bridges with two separate metal centers through the bis-bidentate chelating mode which helps to construct a 1D metal carboxylate zigzag chain which extends along the crystallographic c-axis (Figure S14a for 5 and S16a for 6). These zigzag 1D chains are further linked by the 2-mbib and form a 3D dimondoid architecture in both cases (Figure S14b,c for 5 and S16b,c for 6). Network analysis using TOPOS reveals that the overall structure consists of 4-connected uninodal nets with the point symbol (Schläfli symbol) {66} with a dia net topology (e for 5 and S15e for 6). Here, each metal center node in both cases is attached to two fumarates and two 2-mbib units, forming adamantine-like cages, which are the characteristic building units of the dimondiod net (b,c for 5 and S15b,c for 6). The M···M distances along fum and 2-mbib are 8.805 and 13.909 Å, respectively, for complex 5, whereas they are 9.184 and 14.487 Å, respectively, for complex 6. For these considerablely high M–M distances, large voids are formed within the networks (d and S15d). These large voids are considerably compromised by interpenetration in the networks; four equivalent diamondoid networks are interpenetrated with each other and create a 4-fold interpenetrated diamondoid network (e for 5 and S15e for 6). There are lattice solvent molecules inside the pore of the architecture which are probably held together by H-bonding in between them and/or with the carboxylate oxygen atom.

elements.content: This overall detailed structural analyses suggest that rigidity (or flexibility) of dicarboxylate is the controller for the final structure of these coordination polymers. The N donor ligand having four methylene groups in between bisimidazole systems favors both the interpenetrated and noninterpenetrated systems as we have already discussed in the introduction.

elements.content: For all the complexes, 1–6, PXRD analyses were performed at room temperature, taking the powder samples of each complexes to confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials. In all the complexes there is a good agreement of the entire peak positions between the experimental PXRD patterns and simulated PXRD patterns from their corresponding single crystal structures (Figure S17). This agreement of PXRD patterns confirms the phase purity of the complexes. There is a slight change in PXRD pattern in the as-synthesized form of 1–4. Below 2θ = 10°, one peak was missing or came with lower intensity for each of these complexes. This disappearance is probably attributed to the systematic change of symmetry originated by displacement of disordered lattice water molecules in the powder form of complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)

For all the complexes, 1-6, PXRD analyses were performed at room temperature, taking the powder samples of each complexes to confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials. In all the complexes there is a good agreement of the entire peak positions between the experimental PXRD patterns and simulated PXRD patterns from their corresponding single crystal structures (Figure S17). This agreement of PXRD patterns confirms the phase purity of the complexes. There is a slight change in PXRD pattern in the as-synthesized form of 1-4. Below 2θ = 10°, one peak was missing or came with lower intensity for each of these complexes. This disappearance is probably attributed to the systematic change of symmetry originated by displacement of disordered lattice water molecules in the powder form of complexes.

elements.content: To examine the thermal stability, TGA experiments of all the complexes were performed under an N2 atmosphere (flow rate 10 cm3 min–1) in the temperature range 30−600 °C (for 1−4) and 30−800 °C (for 5 and 6). The combined figures of all the TGA curves have been depicted in Figure S18 and S19. For isostructural complexes 1 and 2, the TGA curves are very similar. Both of the complexes release lattice water molecules nearly in same temperature range. Complex 1 shows 14.60% (calcd, 14.87%) weight loss within 45–95 °C temperature range which indicates loss of four lattice water molecules. The dehydrated structure of this complex shows its stability up to ∼230 °C without further weight loss. On further heating, after 95 °C, the complex dissociates into unidentified product. Whereas complex 2 shows the weight loss at nearly same temperature, it starts at a temperature around 45 °C and ends up at 95 °C. After losing solvent molecules, this framework is steady up to ∼250 °C, causing no weight loss. Beyond 250 °C, it breaks into some unknown product. Complex 3 exhibits 13.06% (calcd, 13.19%) weight loss between 50 and 105 °C. This weight loss indicates the loss of four H-bonded guest water molecules. This dehydrated framework does not show any further weight loss up to ∼245 °C, and it breaks into unknown products after 245 °C. Complex 4 shows 5.30% (calcd, 5.68%) weight loss at 130–200 °C temperature range which indicates the removal of two lattice water molecules. Such high temperature retention of the lattice water may be due to hydrogen boding with the oxygen atoms of the respective carboxylates. The dehydrated structure of 4 is steady up to 340 °C showing no further weight loss and heating above 340 °C drives the complex to be collapsed into unknown products. A weight loss of 4.30% (calcd, 4.34%) is observed for complex 5 within the temperature range 130–170 °C. After removal of guest water molecule the dehydrated framework is stable up to 365 °C and after that temperature the frameworks breaks into unidentified product. This high temperature retention of the guest water molecules also may have caused by the hydrogen bonding of these molecules with the framework. Finally, in case of complex 6, the TGA curve exhibits 6.57% (calcd, 6.72%) weight loss at 90 °C, supporting the loss of one methanol molecule, which starts from ∼35 °C. After loss of the solvents, the framework becomes stable up to 280 °C, and above that temperature, it collapses into unspecified products. For complexes 5 and 6, the TGA was further done up to 800 °C temperature (Figure S19).

elements.content: N2 and CO2 gas sorption measurement of all the activated samples have been carried out to investigate the sorption profile of the complexes by maintaining the proper temperature. For N2 sorption study, the temperature (77 K) was maintained by a liquid nitrogen bath whereas for CO2 (195 K) it was maintained by dry ice-acetone bath. All the complexes 1–6 are activated by heating them at 130 °C, under dynamic vacuum (<10 Torr). All of these activated frameworks have been found as nonporous toward N2 (Figure S20). The possible reason may be N2 molecules, being nonpolar, do not have enough force of attraction toward the 2D structure or in those interpenetrated networks the pore windows are blocked. A similar trend of nonporosity is also found for CO2 sorption (Figure S21). All the complexes show uptake of a negligible amount of CO2. Complexes 4–6 have interpenetration which block the pore hence show negligible gas adsorption. Complexes 1–3 have 2D framework which show only surface adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Studies

N2 and CO2 gas sorption measurement of all the activated samples have been carried out to investigate the sorption profile of the complexes by maintaining the proper temperature. For N2 sorption study, the temperature (77 K) was maintained by a liquid nitrogen bath whereas for CO2 (195 K) it was maintained by dry ice-acetone bath. All the complexes 1-6 are activated by heating them at 130 °C, under dynamic vacuum (<10 Torr). All of these activated frameworks have been found as nonporous toward N2 (Figure S20). The possible reason may be N2 molecules, being nonpolar, do not have enough force of attraction toward the 2D structure or in those interpenetrated networks the pore windows are blocked. A similar trend of nonporosity is also found for CO2 sorption (Figure S21). All the complexes show uptake of a negligible amount of CO2. Complexes 4-6 have interpenetration which block the pore hence show negligible gas adsorption. Complexes 1-3 have 2D framework which show only surface adsorption.

elements.content: We have further studied the H2 (at 77 K) and CH4 (at 298 K) adsorption measurement of all the desolvated complexes. Complexes 1–6 exhibit H2 adsorption 15 cc/g (i.e., 0.13 wt %), 34 cc/g (0.30 wt %), 13.9 cc/g (i.e., 0.12 wt %), 18.2 cc/g (i.e., 0.16 wt %), 57.48 cc/g (i.e., 0.51 wt %), and 38.39 cc/g (i.e., 0.34 wt %), respectively (Figure S22). Hydrogen adsorption of 5 is found to be better than rest of the complexes. For 1–3, all of these complexes are with 2D structure, and it is expected that the ease of hydrogen uptake will be low due to low possibility of trapping of nonpolar hydrogen molecules on the surfaces. On the other hand, complexes 4–6 have 3D structure. So, a similar adsorption amount is expected for all of these complexes. But 5 is with an elongated bond (Cu–O2, 2.718(3) Å), which may be due to Jahn–Teller distortion. During hydrogen adsorption, breakage of this elongated bond may have provided some opening for incoming hydrogen molecules to create a partial coordinate bond to the central Cu­(II) ion. But no such possibility is found for the other two 3D structures. It may be that this is the reason behind the higher uptake of 5. All the complexes exhibit negligible CH4 uptake which may be due to the nonporous nature of the framework toward CH4 (Figure S23).

elements.content: The metal organic frameworks having d10 metal center with π-conjugated organic linkers have drawn persistent interest owing to their use in photoactive material including potential application, such as in selective sensing of small molecules and detection of metal ions. Hence the photoluminescence properties of complexes 2–4 and 6 along with the free 2-mbib linker were measured in the solid state at room temperature (Figure S25). All the excitation wavelength was obtained from UV–vis spectroscopy (Figure S24). The free 2-mbib on photoexcitation at λex = 270 nm exhibit a maximum peak at λem = 471 nm, which can be ascribed to the π* → n or π* → π transitions (Figure S25). For complexes, photoluminescence spectra showed maximum emission peak at 432 nm for 2 (λex = 290 nm), 437 nm for 3 (λex = 290 nm), 432 nm for 4 (λex = 290 nm), and 435 nm for 6 (λex = 290 nm). It can be noticed that the emission bands of complexes 2–4 and 6 have displayed similar maxima positions as that of free 2-mbib ligand with a slight blue shift. As the complexes are with Zn­(II) and Cd­(II), i.e., containing a d10 configuration, the emission cannot be generated by the metal-to-ligand (MLCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), due to the difficulty of oxidation or reduction of d10 metal ions. Hence, the photoluminescence spectra of these complexes can be ascribed to the ligand to ligand or intraligand charge transfer (LLCT), and a ligand dependent emission is expected. The blue shift of photoluminescence spectra of the complexes suggests that on coordination of 2-mbib with the d10 metal system, there is a significant change in the energy level and there is probably enhancement of the energy gap between symmetry accepted electron exchanging orbitals, and this phenomenon is somewhat common for the metal–organic framework.

Luminescent Properties

The metal organic frameworks having d10 metal center with π-conjugated organic linkers have drawn persistent interest owing to their use in photoactive material including potential application, such as in selective sensing of small molecules and detection of metal ions. Hence the photoluminescence properties of complexes 2-4 and 6 along with the free 2-mbib linker were measured in the solid state at room temperature (Figure S25). All the excitation wavelength was obtained from UV-vis spectroscopy (Figure S24). The free 2-mbib on photoexcitation at λex = 270 nm exhibit a maximum peak at λem = 471 nm, which can be ascribed to the π* → n or π* → π transitions (Figure S25). For complexes, photoluminescence spectra showed maximum emission peak at 432 nm for 2 (λex = 290 nm), 437 nm for 3 (λex = 290 nm), 432 nm for 4 (λex = 290 nm), and 435 nm for 6 (λex = 290 nm). It can be noticed that the emission bands of complexes 2-4 and 6 have displayed similar maxima positions as that of free 2-mbib ligand with a slight blue shift. As the complexes are with Zn(II) and Cd(II), i.e., containing a d10 configuration, the emission cannot be generated by the metal-to-ligand (MLCT) or ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), due to the difficulty of oxidation or reduction of d10 metal ions. Hence, the photoluminescence spectra of these complexes can be ascribed to the ligand to ligand or intraligand charge transfer (LLCT), and a ligand dependent emission is expected. The blue shift of photoluminescence spectra of the complexes suggests that on coordination of 2-mbib with the d10 metal system, there is a significant change in the energy level and there is probably enhancement of the energy gap between symmetry accepted electron exchanging orbitals, and this phenomenon is somewhat common for the metal-organic framework.

elements.content: Six transition metal ion based coordination polymers using a flexible N,N′-donor linker (2-mbib) and five different polycarboxylates have been prepared by a slow diffusion technique at room temperature and characterized by different physiochemical techniques. Probable hydrogen-bonding interactions contribute to the creation of the supramolecular architectures. The systematic structural analyses of the complexes suggest that flexible carboxylate is susceptible to form a noninterpenetrated net whereas rigid dicarboxylates are prone to form 3D interpenetrated networks. As for all the instances, the same N donor ligand is used for the design, and it is confirmed that the structural flexibility (or rigidity) of the dicarboxylyate is the determining factor. Conformational changes of flexible networks may have no issues for reformation according to the framework architecture, and thus, those systems are eligible to form noninterpenetrated systems. Whereas for rigid conformation locked systems, there is no possibility to transform according to the network requirement. Thus, it creates extra large voids which are almost compromised by the interpenetration. In summary, this work gives a new hopeful concept to control interpenetration in coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Six transition metal ion based coordination polymers using a flexible N,N'-donor linker (2-mbib) and five different polycarboxylates have been prepared by a slow diffusion technique at room temperature and characterized by different physiochemical techniques. Probable hydrogen-bonding interactions contribute to the creation of the supramolecular architectures. The systematic structural analyses of the complexes suggest that flexible carboxylate is susceptible to form a noninterpenetrated net whereas rigid dicarboxylates are prone to form 3D interpenetrated networks. As for all the instances, the same N donor ligand is used for the design, and it is confirmed that the structural flexibility (or rigidity) of the dicarboxylyate is the determining factor. Conformational changes of flexible networks may have no issues for reformation according to the framework architecture, and thus, those systems are eligible to form noninterpenetrated systems. Whereas for rigid conformation locked systems, there is no possibility to transform according to the network requirement. Thus, it creates extra large voids which are almost compromised by the interpenetration. In summary, this work gives a new hopeful concept to control interpenetration in coordination polymers.

cln_elements.content: To examine the thermal stability, TGA experiments of all the complexes were performed under an N2 atmosphere (flow rate 10 cm3 min–1) in the temperature range 30−600 °C (for 1−4) and 30−800 °C (for 5 and 6). The combined figures of all the TGA curves have been depicted in Figure S18 and S19. For isostructural complexes 1 and 2, the TGA curves are very similar. Both of the complexes release lattice water molecules nearly in same temperature range. Complex 1 shows 14.60% (calcd, 14.87%) weight loss within 45–95 °C temperature range which indicates loss of four lattice water molecules. The dehydrated structure of this complex shows its stability up to ∼230 °C without further weight loss. On further heating, after 95 °C, the complex dissociates into unidentified product. Whereas complex 2 shows the weight loss at nearly same temperature, it starts at a temperature around 45 °C and ends up at 95 °C. After losing solvent molecules, this framework is steady up to ∼250 °C, causing no weight loss. Beyond 250 °C, it breaks into some unknown product. Complex 3 exhibits 13.06% (calcd, 13.19%) weight loss between 50 and 105 °C. This weight loss indicates the loss of four H-bonded guest water molecules. This dehydrated framework does not show any further weight loss up to ∼245 °C, and it breaks into unknown products after 245 °C. Complex 4 shows 5.30% (calcd, 5.68%) weight loss at 130–200 °C temperature range which indicates the removal of two lattice water molecules. Such high temperature retention of the lattice water may be due to hydrogen boding with the oxygen atoms of the respective carboxylates. The dehydrated structure of 4 is steady up to 340 °C showing no further weight loss and heating above 340 °C drives the complex to be collapsed into unknown products. A weight loss of 4.30% (calcd, 4.34%) is observed for complex 5 within the temperature range 130–170 °C. After removal of guest water molecule the dehydrated framework is stable up to 365 °C and after that temperature the frameworks breaks into unidentified product. This high temperature retention of the guest water molecules also may have caused by the hydrogen bonding of these molecules with the framework. Finally, in case of complex 6, the TGA curve exhibits 6.57% (calcd, 6.72%) weight loss at 90 °C, supporting the loss of one methanol molecule, which starts from ∼35 °C. After loss of the solvents, the framework becomes stable up to 280 °C, and above that temperature, it collapses into unspecified products. For complexes 5 and 6, the TGA was further done up to 800 °C temperature (Figure S19).

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

To examine the thermal stability, TGA experiments of all the complexes were performed under an N2 atmosphere (flow rate 10 cm3 min-1) in the temperature range 30-600 °C (for 1-4) and 30-800 °C (for 5 and 6). The combined figures of all the TGA curves have been depicted in Figure S18 and S19. For isostructural complexes 1 and 2, the TGA curves are very similar. Both of the complexes release lattice water molecules nearly in same temperature range. Complex 1 shows 14.60% (calcd, 14.87%) weight loss within 45-95 °C temperature range which indicates loss of four lattice water molecules. The dehydrated structure of this complex shows its stability up to ~230 °C without further weight loss. On further heating, after 95 °C, the complex dissociates into unidentified product. Whereas complex 2 shows the weight loss at nearly same temperature, it starts at a temperature around 45 °C and ends up at 95 °C. After losing solvent molecules, this framework is steady up to ~250 °C, causing no weight loss. Beyond 250 °C, it breaks into some unknown product. Complex 3 exhibits 13.06% (calcd, 13.19%) weight loss between 50 and 105 °C. This weight loss indicates the loss of four H-bonded guest water molecules. This dehydrated framework does not show any further weight loss up to ~245 °C, and it breaks into unknown products after 245 °C. Complex 4 shows 5.30% (calcd, 5.68%) weight loss at 130-200 °C temperature range which indicates the removal of two lattice water molecules. Such high temperature retention of the lattice water may be due to hydrogen boding with the oxygen atoms of the respective carboxylates. The dehydrated structure of 4 is steady up to 340 °C showing no further weight loss and heating above 340 °C drives the complex to be collapsed into unknown products. A weight loss of 4.30% (calcd, 4.34%) is observed for complex 5 within the temperature range 130-170 °C. After removal of guest water molecule the dehydrated framework is stable up to 365 °C and after that temperature the frameworks breaks into unidentified product. This high temperature retention of the guest water molecules also may have caused by the hydrogen bonding of these molecules with the framework. Finally, in case of complex 6, the TGA curve exhibits 6.57% (calcd, 6.72%) weight loss at 90 °C, supporting the loss of one methanol molecule, which starts from ~35 °C. After loss of the solvents, the framework becomes stable up to 280 °C, and above that temperature, it collapses into unspecified products. For complexes 5 and 6, the TGA was further done up to 800 °C temperature (Figure S19).
